conclusion: Solution outline is provided for finding the area S of the cylindrical surface.
Incident rays enter the flat top surface normally as the light is vertical.
Rays are not refracted at entry because they enter normally.
Inside the material, the ray travels straight downward until it strikes the semicircular cylindrical surface.
Let θ be the polar angle at which the ray meets the curved surface.
The angle of incidence on the curved surface equals θ.
Snell’s law determines if the ray refracts out or undergoes total internal reflection.
For n = 2, critical angle θc is 30°.
Rays with θ ≤ θc refract out; rays with θ > θc are totally internally reflected.
Only the cap of the semicircle between θ = 0 and θ = 30° contributes to the emitting area.
Arc length on one side is R θc; on both sides it is 2 R θc.
Cylindrical surface area that emits light is arc length times the length L: S = (2 R θc) L.
Substituting θc = 30° = π/6 radians, S = 2 R (π/6) L = (πRL)/3.
The portion of the curved cylindrical surface through which light emerges has area S = (π R L) / 3.
